Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2017: The genetic basis of host range and specificity in the fungal parasite Escovopsis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, under the program Research Using Biological Collections. The fellow, Caitlin Conn, is conducting research and receiving training that utilizes biological collections in innovative ways, and is being mentored by Nicole Gerardo at Emory University. The postdoctoral fellow is studying the genetic basis of host range in parasites. Parasitism is a type of symbiotic relationship in which one organism (the parasite) benefits at the expense of the other (the host). Over time, parasites often evolve a narrow host range, meaning they specialize on a single host or a group of closely related hosts. However, parasites sometimes evolve compatibility with new hosts, either switching hosts or expanding the number of hosts they can use. Many questions about host-parasite compatibility remain unanswered, especially regarding its genetic basis. To address these questions, the fellow has selected the parasitic fungal genus Escovopsis as a study system. Escovopsis and its fungal hosts have a long coevolutionary history, characterized by specialization of Escovopsis strains on narrow host ranges, and occasional host switching. The fellow will sample an extensive collection of Escovopsis and use cutting-edge tools to investigate the genetic basis of host utilization. The fellow will also design a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) in which introductory biology students will screen for host/parasite compatibility using Escovopsis and an associated collection of hosts. This research will uncover important information about host range, which may extend to parasites that affect humans, livestock, and wildlife. It will also train a postdoctoral fellow in diverse research techniques and provide undergraduates with hands-on research experience.

The fellow will sequence and comparatively analyze the genomes and transcriptomes of Escovopsis strains with different host preferences to determine whether any genomic features or expression patterns are correlated with host range. Genomes will be scanned for positive selection, which may characterize regions that influence host range. Candidate genes will be phylogenetically analyzed and functionally tested by targeted mutation. Finally, an analysis of fine-scale host specificity will be conducted by introductory biology students, who will co-culture Escovopsis samples and potential hosts and observe the outcomes of the interaction. Through this fellowship, the fellow will gain new skills in bioinformatics, ecology, and population genomics by attending courses and seminars and by joining a lab that specializes in these areas. The fellow will also develop teaching skills through the design, implementation, and assessment of the CURE. Results from the studies will be published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at scientific meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Attine ants, which include leaf-cutters and their relatives, are some of the world's oldest farmers. These ants maintain a mutually beneficial symbiotic relationship with fungal cultivars, which they grow and tend to inside of their colonies. Some ant species grow cultivars that belong to a fungal family called the Lepiotaceae; other ant species farm fungi from the Pterulaceae. Although the ants have several adaptations that help them protect their crops, their cultivars are attacked by fungal parasites in the genus Escovopsis. Different strains of Escovopsis have adapted to use different cultivars as hosts.

Brown-spored Escovopsis strains form a monophyletic clade, which means that they're closest relatives of one another. Despite their close evolutionary relationship, some brown-spored strains have evolved with Lepiotaceous cultivars, and some with Pterulaceous cultivars. Yellow- and white-spored Escovopsis strains are more distantly related, but have evolved with Pterulaceous cultivars, much like some brown-spored strains (Figure 1; "Lepio" or "Pter" in Escovopsis strain names refers to cultivar family with which the Escovopsis evolved). It has generally been assumed that Escovopsis strains have specialized on the cultivar hosts with which they evolved; in other words, Escovopsis is thought to have a narrow host range and high specificity for the cultivars it would encounter in nature.

My project funded by the National Science Foundation Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology addressed why closest relatives (i.e. brown-spored strains) use cultivars from different families, while more distantly related parasite strains (i.e. yellow- or white-spored strains and some brown-spored strains) share cultivar hosts in common. While microbial warfare inside ant colonies may seem obscure, Escovopsis serves as a model for addressing a broadly important puzzle: what determines whether a particular parasite is compatible with a particular host? This question, which captures the intellectual merit of my project, has implications for fields such as public health, agriculture, and conservation.

First, because a Lepiotaceae-associated, brown-spored Escovopsis strain already has a sequenced genome, I sequenced the genome of a yellow- or white-spored strain as a comparison. By finding out what genes differ between these two strains, we can begin to investigate the general phenomenon of the genetic basis of host specificity. I also conducted bioassays to test the ability of various Escovopsis strains to use a wide variety of cultivars as hosts. Surprisingly, I found that Escovopsis can sometimes overgrow cultivars with which it has not evolved in nature. For example, while a brown-spored strain that evolved with a Lepiotaceous cultivar seems unable to overgrow Pterulaceous cultivars, it can overcome Lepiotaceous cultivars that are distinct from the one it would encounter in nature. Yellow- and white-spored Escovopsis strains can overcome the Pterulaceous cultivars with which they evolved, but they can also overgrow a few Lepiotaceous cultivars. This finding that host range is not as narrow as previously believed raises a fascinating question: are some Escovopsis strains better at overcoming cultivar hosts with which they have not evolved, or are some cultivars simply more susceptible to attack?

An undergraduate mentee of mine has addressed the latter half of this question by forcing cultivars to interact with the fungal opportunistic human pathogen, Candida albicans. His work will continue after I have moved on to a faculty position elsewhere, but so far he has found that some cultivars seem to produce compounds that inhibit the growth of C. albicans. Other cultivars, including one that is overgrown by brown- and yellow- or white-spored Escovopsis strains, do not inhibit Candida. This suggests that some cultivars, like the one lacking inhibitory effects on Candida and Escovopsis, simply do not make potent defensive compounds, while other cultivars likely do. This student?s goal for the future is to pursue pharmaceutical applications of the antifungal chemicals that some cultivars seem to make.

Through this fellowship, I was also able to mentor a high school student in the lab, and I taught Evolutionary Biology at Emory University and Immunology & Disease at a Tibetan Buddhist monastery in India. I presented my research at a scientific conference and a meeting of the Mushroom Club of Georgia. In pursuing broader impacts such as mentoring, teaching, and communicating science, I enhanced my understanding of this system and prepared myself for the professorship I will begin in August 2019 at Berry College. As I move on in my career, I will continue to analyze the Escovopsis genome that I sequenced, to study gene expression in this parasite, and to prepare a manuscript on my work for publication. Overall, this fellowship has been a tremendous learning experience, has impacted the study of Escovopsis and the scientific and non-specialist communities, and has enabled me to reach my goal of becoming a professor.
